mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: It matches up two comic actors and instead of clashing or canceling each other out, they bring in the best possible result: A comedy with twice the laughs.

Ferrell and Hart don’t bring anything that we haven’t seen from them before, but they create a bouncy, playfully defiant rapport. It’s promising enough that you wish they could have made a movie in which they’re just making us laugh, instead of leaving us wondering how every third scene could be made less offensive.
Dumb, juvenile comedy has its place when it's funny. Unfortunately, too often in Get Hard, it's not.
Laughter trumps political fairness, and Get Hard made me laugh at, and with, situations I hadn’t thought could tickle me. The movie has a warm heart beating under its seemingly scabrous shell.

Miraculously, the movie doesn’t feel mean-spirited so much as profoundly awkward. Scripted by smart guys like Etan Cohen (Idiocracy, Tropic Thunder) and two behind-the-scenes writers on TV’s consistently excellent Key & Peele, the film feels both daring and foolhardy.
I don’t believe that Get Hard sets out to be hurtful, and there are some good gags... but it does seem dumb and dated.
The germ of an interesting idea in Get Hard is completely overshadowed by the onslaught of jokes meant to be boundary-pushing and edgy.
If you love rape jokes, Get Hard is your movie.

It's all wildly uneven, but some bits really are funny. Ferrell plays his usual clueless character, but he's good at it. And it turns out a toned-down Hart is a funnier Hart. But Cohen can't keep a handle on it all. Worse, he has no feel for when the satire goes too far.

From its juvenile double entendre title to its fascination with prison rape and homophobic humor, “Get Hard” practically announces itself as an offensive, tired and unimaginative comedy in nearly every scene. And yet I didn’t hate it because Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart had such terrific comedic chemistry.
Ferrell and Hart have a genial, easygoing chemistry and Get Hard manages to score more than a few good points about facile assumptions and toxic hypocrisy.
Ferrell and Hart are too likable and crowd-pleasing to let the movie collapse around them. But they’re also too talented for something this wan.
Get Hard is most comfortable — and funny — when Cohen gets back to skewering class warfare.

Ferrell is as fearless as ever, stripping down and looking foolish, willing to be out-of-touch and out of step. Hart has his manic moments. But in this buddy comedy, the buddies are not equal and that limits the laughs.
A passably silly but lowbrow buddy comedy.
Get Hard is not only a bad movie but a profoundly wasted opportunity.
Laughs are few and far between in a comedy that proves the combo of talented performers and an intriguing concept are no guarantee of success. Dispiriting stuff.

The real problem is that Get Hard’s very idea of edge is itself pretty stale. It feels like a bunch of off-color jokes the filmmakers have been trying to tell for years, and they’ve crammed them all into one film — with tiresome results.
Is it funny enough to make for a wholly satisfying feature-length film? No, not really. Like so many films of Ferrell's, Get Hard feels rushed and uneven.
The highest praise I can give Get Hard is that it is not quite as awful as it could have been.

Asking little of its stars, and even less of any watching audience, Get Hard is a familiar studio comedy that barely succeeds in its attempt to drown out a thin plot with jokes that will appeal to people who have seen a lot of the actors' previous films. Perhaps the offensive thing about it is that we've seen this all before.
Get Hard just gets increasingly hard to put up with, full stop.
Belying its title, this is a pretty flaccid offering which fails to gel the comedy stylings of Hart and Ferrell.
A raunchy yet slack-feeling comedy that seems to put as much effort into playing on racial stereotypes as playing for laughs.
Riding that fine line between misjudged and deliberately anti-p.c., Get Hard is lewd, crude and rude but, despite its disastrous reception at SxSW, not entirely unfunny.
Audiences are going to want to brace themselves, too – for a movie that refuses to recognize when it’s going too far, with its wince-eliciting jokes about jailhouse rape in particular.

If the jokes in Get Hard were a set of Jeopardy categories, they’d read as follows: Things Will Ferrell Puts Up His Butt, Butt Rape, Shots of Will Ferrell’s Bare Butt and Satirical Comparisons of Violent and Nonviolent Crime Not Excluding Mentions of Balzac.
Get Hard is hard to sit through and hardly funny. So unless you're really hard up for entertainment, stay away from this tone-deaf raunchfest.
It's not easy hanging talents like Ferrell and Hart out to dry. But Get Hard gets the job done. It's one limp noodle.
Get Hard... is certainly a better name than, say, Laugh Hard, which you won't do nearly enough.

The deathly silence doomed to haunt theaters during Get Hard allows audiences far too much time to think about its problematic attitudes toward race, gender, sexuality, and class, as well as its borderline-nonsensical plot.
Whatever one makes of Get Hard’s contribution to our ongoing national debate about race, class and sexuality, there’s no denying that too much of it simply feels cheap, flailing and tired.
It's OK to rip off/pay homage to a better movie, but the idea is to improve on it, and ideas one thing that's completely missing from Get Hard.

Get Hard becomes an increasingly unpleasant comedy, wasting two very funny stars in a barrage of prison rape gags, lazy stereotypes, toilet stall indignities and insincere acceptance of people already marginalized in movies.
This mess is guilty of being both racist and homophobic. And it’s as shamelessly lazy and crude as its title suggests.
It's a mystery why two bona fide comic stars, working very, very hard to keep this thing from tanking, couldn't pressure their collaborators for another rewrite or three.
The filmmakers largely stand out of Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart's way, but they also refuse to modulate the story's racial humor with any sense of subversion.
Competently made but morally repellent, Get Hard may be my least favorite Will Ferrell feature film.

Funny bits come along every now and then, and the co-stars work desperately hard for their salaries. But the spectacle is depressing for what it says of mainstream studio standards. Grinding on with dim humor and grim purpose, Get Hard gets ever harder to take.

Cohen had neither the chops nor the clout to prevent Get Hard from ending up, no doubt through the normal process of producer rewrites, focus groups, worried agents and weevil infestations, as a confused and contradictory mess. More to the point, it’s almost never funny, and full of elementary screenwriting blunders.
Get Hard isn’t edgy enough to be offensive or witty enough to be challenging. It’s just dumb.

It's an absolutely horrible, amateurishly assembled comedy that is more offensive than just about anything we've seen lately, a non-stop parade of racist, homophobic bile that would be bad enough from any comedian, but coming out of Ferrell and Hart has the effect of watching a childhood hero committing some horrible act.
Beyond a leper’s handful of jokes that actually connect, this might as well be Ferrell’s most abysmal piece of work since the disastrous "Land of the Lost."

mc_user_reviews.text: Albeit there are some funny parts, such as Will Ferrell's character explaining economics to gangsters, this movie is just one tired out middle school prison rape joke with racial stereotypes.

Just got back from seeing this movie, and I am surprised to see that the critical reaction has been not-so-good. My friend and I both laughed out loud a number of times. Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart are both just naturally funny people, and if you like their type of humor, you will enjoy this movie.

The first 20 minutes of so of the movie are pretty mediocre but they set the stage for the hilarity that ensues in the next hour plus, where Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart are comedic geniuses. They play the same roles they typically do, with Hart being a pint-sized black man with a lot of bark and little bite and Ferrell being the big, lumbering air head who's innocence and ignorance somehow make him endearing and obnoxious at the same time. However, those roles blend together perfectly in this movie as the two have great on-screen chemistry. The supporting cast is also fantastic and this movie is, overall, a really good comedy that most people will likely enjoy.

Bafflingly unfunny considering some of the talent involved, "Get Hard" is a stereotype-ridden disappointment that misfires with most of its jokes and bungles the opportunity of chemistry between its leads.

Not the funniest movie I've ever seen in my life and my expectations were high, but Get Hard is still pretty funny and I suggest any fan of Will Ferrell or Kevin Hart see this movie. I think the racism was a little over hyped, sure there is some racist humour but its not as plentiful as the critics have been saying. Will Ferrell is really funny as he always is and Kevin Hart wasn't bad either, he had some pretty funny moments. One of the things that was disappointing about Get Hard was that they were putting too many jokes in that were just not funny and there were several but other than that I would enjoy seeing another movie with Ferrell and Hart together and it seems like the two have bonded over the shooting of the movie and I would not be shocked to see it.
"Get Hard" 10 Scale Rating: 5.5 (Decent) ...

Get Hard tries to be a over the top, racist, profane and vulgar comedy. But the laughs are overused, and add no spice to the aging theme. The story plays out with James King (Will Ferrell) who gets convicted of a felony he never committed, and he gets sentenced to 5 years in a maximum security prison in San Quentin. James uses the help of his car washer, Darnell Lewis (Kevin Hart) to teach him the basics of prison, and how he can survive in the godforsaken place. But, Darnell never went to prison! Get Hard uses James to use his racist stereotypes against Lewis to make it funny. Sure, Kevin Hart does his best, and gives us some belly laughs, but Will Ferrell's racist, rich and totally bonkers, James King is one of the worst things about Get Hard. The pair do well together, even against the badly written script, the mediocre direction and the bland story, to create a funny movie. I appreciate the ways Get Hard takes you under the "hood" of prisons, and tells you about rape, and assaults in prison from a funny perspective. And, T.I gives a good performance as a Crenshaw Kings boss. All this, could have summed up to a really funny movie, but Get Hard doesn't try enough to get that medal. It's badly written, racist, offensive and gives us the worst Will Ferrell performance in years. But, if you don't get offended easily, Get Hard may be fun for you.

Hart and Ferrell could read sections out of the phone book, and we'd still laugh.  So no, the material isn't as good as you'd expect given both of their previous work, but there are plenty of laughs to sustain you.
Feels like they just made it up as they went along.  Sometimes that works...well, not really, and it doesn't work here either.  More proof that Kevin Hart USED to be funny.

An abysmal failure of a film on nearly every level. Scattered minor funny jokes are what saves it from me a zero. The movie left me with a headache and a sickness of what comedies have become today. Absolutely  horrible.

Just like in my Unfinished Business review as I explained why I watched it and all that stuff...well for this one I checked it out myself just because I had a little interest for this movie and wow talking about a miss fire this movie was. This is going to be a short review for this garage movie, why well I haven't got anything else to say about it because why should I go into such much detail for this movie that I will not remember it in a few days time.
I cannot remember the last time I laughed so hard watching a movie in theatres! And that is countless years at least. I thoroughly enjoyed every part of it.
I get it. Kevin Hart is laughing all the way to the bank. But I wanna laugh, too.  When I shell out 14 bucks.
An old concept with a new pair.
loved this movie, I love the characters, will was funny in this movie but the only problem would be the racial stereotype jokes plus kevin hart wasn't annoying in this one so that's a plus.

Get Hard is moderately funny, but it's uneven humor can't transcend the racism, cliches, and sheer stupidity. The film is full of flat underdeveloped characters, that you never feel for, and the plot which had some potential falls flat, partially due to sporadic pacing. That being said if you shut your brain off the film has it's moments, and Ferrel and Hart have great chemistry.
Hilarious Comedy, I have no idea how this is is getting negative reception... Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart manage to be a comedy duo that is just flatout hysterical

Ok so I knew from the Preivews that it wasn't  going to be a smart comedy that u don't have to really think to enjoy and that's just what I did I really am missing something here I guess I thought it was fine I laughed alot enjoyed the plot and story of friendship I say go see for yourself trust me u will have a blast

So, apparently, a guy tries to learn how to survive in prison. Honestly, it's not that bad. Well, sure, there were some racism, rape, etc. but, it has some funny moments. Especially that police riot training scene. It made me laugh to the floor. If you are into Kevin Hart and Will Ferrell, you should see it. If not, well, you should at least see it anyway. My suggestion, go check out the movie.

When a pompous investment banker (Will Farrell) is convicted of a crime, he hires the only black man he knows (Kevin Hart) to prepare him for prison. The premise is promising, but the movie relies on lame predictable subjects (gay panic, racial stereotypes, obvious villains) instead of genuine comic writing. Hart's motor mouth provides most of laffs, while Farrell's broad, buffoon style is often annoying. There are memorable out comic moments and almost nobody in the supporting cast adds any humor (T.J. Jagodowski's friendly gay is an exception). The dialogue feels like writer/director Elan Cohen let the 2 leads improvise most of the bits and didn't exercise any control on their effusive styles. Their chemistry's not bad and there are some funny parts, but more often it just tries too hard.

I hate when people complain about offensive humour (talking to all the feminazis, SJW's, neckbeard MRA's and culture vultures) because it is mindlessly immature and funny in situation like this. To start, this movie had a decent premise, kevin hart has to teach wil ferrell to survive in jail. Awesome idea for a comedy. Does this movie fulfil it's potential? Kinda. On one hand, the chemistry between the two actors is great, I love how will ferrel has to fit in with the ghetto and I loved the amount of slapstick comedy this had to offer. However, there were some points in the movie where I thought it would be easier to just move the conversation along as nothing particularly funny was happening. Overall, Get Hard will make you laugh for the majority of your experience and is filled with offensive humour and stereotypes.

Okay, I should start off by saying I love Will Ferrell movies, so am biased.  Also, I work at a prison so know exactly what they are talking about in the scenes.  So, if you DON'T love Will and don't know much about prison life, you may not like this, but I really enjoyed it.  It's not a GREAT movie like Blades of Glory was, but it's GOOD and enjoyable, and the cast is great.  Lots of stereotypes are made fun of, and as usual Will is fun to watch.

Comedy finds a winning duo in Hart and Ferrell. The two are able to bounce jokes off of another with ease thanks to their surprising chemistry. Ferrell does what he does best here, and that's playing an over-the-top and absurd character. Hart's character is more down to earth and tasked with preparing this airhead for prison despite not actually going there himself.

The story of a rich businessman employing a black valet to help him prepare for a prison term seems like a rich vein for comedy, unfortunately here it is seen as a vehicle for misogynistic and homophobic low brow laughs that fall very flat. There are a couple of good laughs but they are mostly buried under an avalanche of insulting stereotypes and unfunny improvisation. As with most of Ferrell's recent films the director seems reluctant to call cut, allowing scenes already unfunny to drag on interminably. Ferrell is due a return to form at some point, but this isn't it.

As average as most of Will Ferrells movies unfortunately, I'm sure he can do better than that. Summing up: an average comedy movie making fun of stereotypes about black people and prison life. I guess you can watch this if you have nothing better to do, but otherwise it's not worth it.
Another disappointing comedy.  Kevin Hart and Will Ferrell have potential to make a classic instead they made a film obsessed with racial stereo types and prison rape.  D
Right at the start it is offensive and not really funny just shocking.  Did they make this movie so we would become disgusted with anything Gay or hate anything to do with white men.

I appreciate what Etan Cohen's Get Hard has to do and has to offer, I loved Get Hard! It's not the best R-rated comedy but I loved that it's roars it's R rating, and is laugh out loud funny at times, and the chemistry that Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart is easy going. James King (Will Ferrell) is a rich and is a financial analyst  he has a huge mansion in Bel Air, lives with a soon to be married beautiful fiancé Allissa (Allison Brie) and is promoted by Allissa's father Martin (Craig T. Nelson). Kevin Hart plays Darnell he is a hardworking car wash operator, lives in Crenshaw with his supporting wife Rita (Edwina Findley Dickerson) also smart daughter Makalya (Ariana Neal). Darnell wants to get Makayla and Rita out of the neighborhood and school hoping his daughter will go to another school. James is convicted and fraud sentenced to 10 years in San Quetitin. So he wants Darnell, the guy who washes his car, to help him survive in prison Darnell didn't go to prison, James just thinks he did because of his skin color. James is flat out racist, I honestly didn't care if he goes to prison or not that's how unlikeable he is. The cheap script by Etan Cohen (Tropic Thunder), Ian Roberts (Martin & Orloff) and Jay Martal gives us a few laughs here and there but honestly they know better than this mediocrity so does Ferrell and Hart but they make this mediocrity funny at times. The talented Allison Brie and Craig T. Nelson are miss cast they put nothing good here to the table playing charactures. 3.0/4 stars
This film is set up against a despicable backdrop of

"Get Hard" Is the newest comedy from Will Ferrell and Kevin Heart, It's a buddy comedy based around Kevin Heart teaching Will Ferrell's character how he will survive in prison as a old white guy.The humor is this movie if very offensive and vulgar but is what you come to expect from this type of comedy. Some jokes are extremely funny and the addition of great improve between Kevin and Will really adds to the jokes, but some jokes fall horribly flat. Most other actors in the film don't leave much of an impression on you, most of them only appear at the beginning or end of the film. Will and Kevin work great together in this film and if your a fan of buddy comedy's I'm sure you will enjoy this but "Get Hard" Isn't anything special.

Below average. The film relies heavily on stereotypes, racism and homophobia to get it's laughs. The film has a "countdown" premise, where the main character James King (Ferrell) has just a month to get prepared for jail by his mentor Darnell (Kevin Hart) for a crime that he didn't commit. I feel like Ferrell has a lot more comedic lines than Hart and that Hart was there mainly so that Ferrell could make the jokes. The best way I can put it is:
I wonder if Kevin Hart and Will Ferrell wake up in the morning and say "I'm sure glad I made that puerile piece of **** "Get Hard" and managed to offend everyone who watched it".
The movie lacks originality.  The movie overuses vulgar and racist comedy .  The movie had some funny parts but for the most part I was bored and could not wait for the movie to end.
Okay... This is way too underrated. I know it is not perfect and funny as ride along but seriously... The cast is strong, both actors were great, and the plot was just you average comedy plot.

Get Hard is supposed to be a comedy, but during the entire movie I laughed about three times. The movie ain´t interesting, and while it brings a creative story it fails on reproducing it. The acting by the main characters, Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart, isn´t bad at all and they do try to makes us laugh but they fail completely.

It has it moments. There's a few quotes from this movie that has me laughing pretty hard. It was worth the rental for sure. It's not amazing, but some of the lines are just hilarious. Not everyone's best work, but a solid showing regardless. I wasn't looking for perfection in story telling, I just wanted to laugh, and this flick did it for me.
Get Hard strives to be completely funny and exciting, but fails to do so. There may be some laughs present, but besides that, Get Hard is not anything worth remembering.
Why would I want to 'Get Hard' when this movie should 'Get Hard' to try any new ideas for at least once? Come up with at least new ideas when making this movie.
A funny movie with a funny title. Not for kids by the way. I wouldn't recommend this title, but I think it is funny enough to give it a 9/10. Thank you
I thought it was pretty funny. I enjoy a good Will Farrell movie even though they can go one way or the other.. Happy to say with Kevin Hart this was a good match and I laughed quite a bit.
hILARIOUS FILM. NOT THAT BAD. WATCH IT FOR A GREAT LAUGH. NOT FOR KIDS THOUGH. this is rated r. see the other guys with kids. this is an adult film but its a good one.
